title: How 3D, Sound, Digital Twins, and XR Help Protect Musical History
content: Preserving a historic musical instrument is not only about protecting its wood, metal, or varnish. For wind instruments, especially historic pipe organs and their ancient predecessors such as the Hydraulis, heritage also lives in movement, airflow, sound, and the spaces where the music is heard. These instruments are often mechanically complex and very fragile. Many cannot be played or handled frequently without risk of damage.
